Description: Body sherd of Milesian Fikellura pottery neck-amphora; exterior, white slip: painted decoration consisting of komast facing left and lifting a cup to his lips (lower part of face, left arm and part of chest remaining); at left, possible shoulder and arm of second komast.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos incorrectly identifies the sherd as belonging to a Chian black-figure Komast chalice and places it in Group E of the black-figure Komast chalices. The chalices in this group do not contain any filling ornament, details of the komasts are rendered very simply and inner decoration is basic. The iconography on this sherd is different from typical komast chalices and there is no evidence of black-figure incision. Schaus lists the sherd as probably belonging to the Altenburg Painter. According to Cook's classification system, the sherd belongs in the Cambridge Group (named after Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.52.1899, GR.302.1899 and GR.303.1899); the human figures are rudimentary but resemble those from the Altenburg Group. See Cook 1933-1934 pls. 5, 6, 11c, for the group's namepiece, the amphora, Altenburg 191.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 172, p. 329, no. 1555, pl. 198)
Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 111, no. 321.14, pl. XXXIV)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 246, no. 10)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 216, no. 48)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GF.018)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4757 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
